dua.arabic: اَلحَمدُ لِلهِ الَّذِي أحيَانَا بَعْدَ مَا أمَاتَنَا وَ إِلَيهِ النُّشُورُ
dua.translation: Praise is to Allāh Who gives us life after He has caused us to die and to Him is the return.
dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#6312), see Fatḥ al-Bārī (11/113), and Muslim (#2711, 4/2083).

dua.arabic: لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللهُ وَحْدَهُ لَا شَرِيكَ لَهُ، لَهُ الْمُلْكُ وَلَهُ الحَمدُ، وَهُوَ عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ، سُبْحاَنَ اللهِ، وَالحَمدُ للهِ، وَلَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللهُ وَاللهُ أَكْبَرُ، وَلَا حَوْلَ وَلَا قُوَّةَ إِلَّا بِاللهِ الْعَلِيِّ الْعَظِيمِ، رَبِّ اغْفِرْ لِي
dua.translation: There is none worthy of worship but Allāh alone, Who has no partner, His is the dominion and to Him belongs all praise, and He is able to do all things. Glory is to Allāh. Praise is to Allāh. There is none worthy of worship but Allāh. Allāh is the Most Great. There is no might and no power except by Allāh's leave, the Exalted, the Mighty. My Lord, forgive me. (Whoever says this will be forgiven, and if he supplicates to Allāh, his prayer will be answered; if he performs ablution and prays, his prayer will be accepted.)
dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#1154), see Fatḥ al-Bārī (3/39). The wording is of Ibn Mājah (#3878), also see Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Mājah (2/335).

dua.arabic: الحَمدُ لِلهِ الَّذِي عَافَانِي فِي جَسَدِي، وَرَدَّ عَلَيَّ رُوحِي، وَأَذِنَ لِي بِذِكْرِهِ
dua.translation: Praise is to Allāh Who gave strength to my body, He returned my soul to me and permitted me to remember Him.

dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#4572), see Fatḥ al-Bārī (8/237) and Muslim (#763, 1/530).

dua.arabic: اَلحَمدُ لِلهِ الَّذِي كَسَانِي هَذَا (الثَّوْبَ) وَرَزَقَنِيهِ مِنْ غَيْرِ حَولٍ مِنِّي وَ لَا قُوَّةٍ
dua.translation: Praise is to Allāh Who has clothed me with this (garment) and provided it for me, though I was powerless myself and incapable.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#4023) and the wording is his, al-Tirmidhī (#2458) and Ibn Mājah (#3285). Also see Irwāʾ al-Ghalīl (7/47).

dua.arabic: اللَّهُمَّ لَكَ الحَمدُ أَنْتَ كَسَوْتَنِيهِ، أَسْأَلُكَ مِنْ خَيْرِهِ وَخَيْرِ مَا صُنِعَ لَهُ، وَأَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنْ شَرِّهِ وَشِّرِ مَا صُنِعَ لَهُ
dua.translation: O Allāh, for You is all praise, You have clothed me with it (i.e. the garment), I ask You for the good of it and the good for which it was made, and I seek refuge with You from the evil of it and the evil for which it was made.
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#4020) and al-Tirmidhī (#1767) and al-Baghawī. The wording is from Abū Dāwud. Also see Mukhtaṣar Shamāʾil al-Tirmidhī by Al-Albānī (p.\ 47).

group.title: Supplication said to someone wearing new clothes

dua.translation: May you wear it out and Allāh replace it (with another).
dua.reference: Abū Dāwud (#4020, 4/41). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ Abī Dāwud (2/760).

dua.arabic: إِلبَسْ جَدِيداً، وَعِشْ حَمِيداً، وَمُتْ شَهِيداً
dua.translation: Wear anew, live commendably and die a martyr.
dua.reference: Ibn Mājah (#3558, 2/1178) and al-Baghawī (12/41). Also see Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Mājah (2/275).
Al-Tirmidhī (#606, 2/505) and Sahīh al-Jāmiʿ (#3210, 3/203). Also see Irwāʾ al-Ghalīl (#50).

dua.arabic: (بِسْمِ اللهِ) اللَّهُمَّ إِنِّي أَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنَ الْخُبْثِ وَالْخَبَائِثِ
dua.translation: (In the name of Allāh). O Allāh, I take refuge with you from all evil and evil-doers.
dua.reference: Al-Bukhārī (#142, 1/45) and Muslim (#375, 1/283). The narration with the extension "In the name of Allāh" has been collected by Saʿīd bin Manṣūr, see Fatḥ al-Bārī (1/244).
Al-Tirmidhī (#7), Abū Dāwud (#30), Ibn Mājah (#300), and al-Nasāʾī in ʿAmal al-Yawm wa al-Laylah (#79). Also see the takhrīj of Zād al-Maʿād (2/386).
